title: Hilbert's 11th Problem: Quadratic Forms
description: Classification of quadratic forms over number fields. The Hasse-Minkowski theorem provides a local-global principle for rational solutions.

overview.historicalContext: Hilbert's 11th Problem asks for the classification of quadratic forms with algebraic number coefficients. The key result is the Hasse-Minkowski theorem, which provides a local-global principle.
overview.problemStatement:
**Problem:** When does a quadratic form Q(x1,...,xn) = sum aij*xi*xj have a non-trivial zero over the rationals?

**Theorem (Hasse-Minkowski):** Q has a non-trivial rational zero iff it has non-trivial zeros over R and all p-adic fields Qp.
overview.proofStrategy:
The local-global principle reduces global questions to local ones:
1. Check solvability over the reals
2. Check solvability over each p-adic field
3. If all local conditions pass, a global solution exists
keyInsights: Local-global principles connect number theory and analysis
The Hasse principle fails for some higher-degree equations
Quadratic forms have a complete classification theory

sections.title: Quadratic Forms

conclusion.summary: The Hasse-Minkowski theorem provides a beautiful characterization of when quadratic forms have rational zeros, reducing global questions to local ones.
conclusion.implications: This theorem is fundamental to algebraic number theory and led to extensive study of when local-global principles hold or fail.
openQuestions: When does the Hasse principle fail?
How do we extend to number fields?
